title: 13 Best Face Sunscreens Our Editors Tested and Loved in 2025
article_text: All products are independently selected by our editors. If you buy something, we may earn an affiliate commission. Last year, we wrote that, without embellishment, the best skin care advice we can give you is to wear the best face sunscreen (a.k.a.broad spectrum SPF) every single day. And, we pretty much nailed it. SPFs guard against UVA and UVB rays that cause sunburns and skin cancer as well aswrinkles, loss of elasticity,hyperpigmentation, redness, and all-aroundpissed off skin. Skin without ‘em is bummed out and burned out by the end of summer, which is no good for anyone. But look, we also know that a lot of SPFs kinda suck. They can be goopy and pasty; they can smell weird and cause breakouts; they can leave a white cast on skin and some streakiness if not applied properly. And if a formula checks one of those boxes, it’s enough to make you not want to wear it. So, to ensure that you don’t have to deal with any of that and instead just reap the benefits, we put a bunch of formulas through the ringer. Here, the best face sunscreens for everyone—no matter whether you want a physical blocker, a chemical blocker, an SPF moisturizer, or a tinted sunscreen. Ultra Violette Sephora Formula:Chemical (Avobenzone 3% Homosalate 7% Octisalate 5% Octocrylene 8%) |Key active ingredients:squalane and pentavitin for hydration and barrier protection |Water resistant?80 minutes |Size(s):1.7 fl. oz. ​​Why we like it:The Aussie sunscreen brand that had a million skin care devotees polling their friends on when they were traveling to the Sunshine Coast is as dreamy as the reputation that precedes it. On skin, it feels cushiony and plush like a moisturizer that gives just enough hydration to skin without weighing it down. Sometimes SPF can be goopy and hard to layer with other products, but this one feels light and layerable. Who it’s best for:So long as you’re looking for a chemical filter, this SPF can work for all skin types. It does have skin-supporting and skin-hydrating ingredients, so if you’re someone who wants to cut out a few skin care steps, look no further. About the formula:Because the United Stateshas outdated sunscreen filters(TL;DR: the FDA regulates SPF actives and hasn’t yet approved the filters that are used in many other countries over yonder), the formula doesn’t mimic the Australian formula completely. In the U.S. rendition of the legendary Ultra Violette Supreme Screen, a cocktail of avobenzone, octinoxate, octocrylene, and homosalate replaces bemotrizinol, bisoctrizole, and a few other actives, but you still get the other skin-soothing ingredients like squalane and pentavitin. Coola Amazon Sephora Formula:Chemical (Avobenzone 1.75% Homosalate 5.0% Octisalate 2.0% Octocrylene 5.0%)| Key active ingredients:Antioxidant plant complex of red raspberry seed oil, meadowfoam oil, prickly pear extract to defend against toxins and UV damage| Water resistant?80 minutes| Size(s):1.7 fl. oz. Our tester’s take:If you find a sunscreen to add to yourskin care routinethat is something you look forward to wearing, then you know it’s a good one. That means you’ll actually want to apply it alongside your dailymoisturizerbefore going outside, which will help to preventskin aging. Because of its elegant application and breathability—especially when I’m working up a sweat—grooming writer Adam Hurly wholeheartedly recommends it. Who it’s best for:Coola’s SPF option works well for acne-prone skin, oily skin, and sensitive skin individuals, and it has 80 minutes of water and sweat resistance. I wear it comfortably before jogging under the sun, or whenever I think I’ll be sweating between errands or simply sprawling out in the park. About the formula:The formula has a little bit of a melting texture that needs no encouragement to sink right into skin. Once applied, it wears slightly shiny for the first 30 minutes or so, but it settles down nicely after that. Coola’s SPFs are enhanced with plant actives and antioxidants—red raspberry seed oil, buriti oil, meadowfoam seed oil, and prickly pear extract—that help to guard against free radical damage on skin, so if you’re looking for a single product in addition to a moisturizer or daily serum, this could be an easy win. Augustinus Bader Dermstore Formula:Mineral (Titanium Dioxide 9.102%%; Zinc Oxide 13.175%) |Key active ingredients:TCF8, a proprietary ingredient aimed at cell renewal; microalgae and cotton seed extract protect against photodamage, and buriti oil and raspberry seed oil provide antioxidant protection for free radical defense |Water resistant?80 minutes |Size(s):1.6 fl. Oz. Our tester’s take:It’s hard to find an SPF that we’d recommend shelling out $140 for, but Augustinus Bader has us standing here preaching from the rooftops. The formula goes onto skin and, without too much maneuvering, blends seamlessly. It has a bit of a velvety texture that doesn’t leave too much shine on skin once its in place. Thanks to a whole who’s who of skin care ingredients, it’s also easy to pare back the number of products I’m using when this SPF is on my countertop (including the brand’s proprietary TCF8—more on that in a sec). Who it’s best for:People looking for a mineral sunscreen that doesn’t feel chalky on skin or leave behind too much streakiness. It helps if they have a little change rolling around in their pockets, because this stuff definitely doesn’t come cheap. About the formula:Zinc oxide heavy formulas can leave a white cast on skin, but this formula does a solid job at blending down nicely. Beyond the active SPF filters, this formula contains an ingredient that Professor Bader originally created as part of a burn cream. When he saw how effective it was at repairing compromised skin, he brought it to a wider audience in his moisturizers, creating the brand we know and love today. In its use at the heart of this SPF, the formula helps to support skin evenness, hydration, and reduce fine lines. EltaMD Amazon Dermstore Formula:Hybrid chemical-mineral (Zinc Oxide 9%, Octinoxate 7.5%)| Key active ingredients:Cyclomethicone for lightweight hydration; niacinamide for barrier fortification| Water resistant?Not formally tested for it.| Size(s):1.7 fl. oz. Our tester’s take:EltaMD is a fave of dermatologists because of its robust protection. This option combines mineral and chemical filters, allowing it to blend imperceptibly on darker skin tones without leaving a white cast. NYC-based board-certified dermatologistAsmi Sanghvi, MD gives this SPF two thumbs up: “This is my favorite facial sunscreen,” she says. Who it’s best for:According to Dr. Sanghvi? Everyone. But our rosacea-prone tester particularly liked it (as well as the brand’s newGreen Tint Broad Spectrum SPF 50) for redness. “It is lightweight, non-comedogenic, and is suitable for all skin types, including acne-prone and sensitive skin, and provides excellent protection without leaving a white cast or greasy residue.” The formula:We like this formula a lot because it gives you the best of both worlds around the clock. For starters, it comes in both tinted and non-tinted versions. The tinted version is a solid mineral option for darker skin tones to help prevent a white cast on skin. It also has multiple sun filters so that you can get the benefits of a mineral SPF in a more cosmetically elegant formula. Supergoop Sephora Nordstrom Formula:Chemical (Avobenzone 3%, Homosalate 10%, Octisalate 5%, Octocrylene 7.5%)| Key active ingredients:Rosemary leaf and sunflower extracts for antioxidant defense| Water resistant?80 minutes| Size(s):2.4, 5.5, and 18 fl. oz. Why it’s great:Hurly says he never travels without his giant refill of Supergoop’s Play sunscreen in tow because this SPF covers all his needs—whether hitting the beach or exploring a new city. Supergoop’s entire range of sunscreen products is one of the best options in the United States, and could compete with the many of the options overseas where there are more updated sun filters like Tinosorb and Uvinul. This product, in particular, is the brand’s most universal, given its full-body wear, lightweight application, and 80-minute water resistance. Who it’s best for:Anyone looking for a head-to-toe SPF product that is layerable, easy to wear, and relatively inexpensive. The formula:When you think: “classic sunscreen” this formula comes to mind. It goes onto skin, sinking in seamlessly and blending imperceptibly, thanks to its chemical formula. Because of a host of skin-supporting ingredients—sunflower, rosemary, and rice bran extracts—it fends off environmental aggressors and feels more like a moisturizer than most. Plus, its 80-minute water resistance makes it a great choice for folks who are active or hitting the beach. Cardon Cardon Amazon (2-pack) Formula:Chemical (Avobenzone, Homosalate, Octisalate)| Key active ingredients:Cactus extract soothes and hydrates skin; turmeric provides anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and antimicrobial abilities, while chia seed extract provides oger-3-powered defense.| Water resistant?Not formally tested for it.| Size(s):1.2 fl. Oz. Our tester’s take:Cardon’s core products are the perfect baseline regimen for most men (see: Hurley’s praise for them in these posts aboutgel moisturizerandclay face wash). This SPF moisturizer combines two imperative morning skin care steps into one with a pocket-size product that travels easily and lasts much longer than you’d expect. Its anti-inflammatory, hydrating, and antioxidant ingredients make it a superb moisturizer, but the inclusion of chemical UV defenses rounds it out for minimalists who want to wear a product that does it all. Who it’s best for:People who want a moisturizer that doubles up on sun protection. It’s a one-and-done product that gives you the protection you need. About the formula:You might think that because it’s a moisturizer the formula is slightly thicker than other SPFs, but that’s not the case with Cardon. It manages to feel light and silky on skin while still packing in ingredients that help keep your skin hydrated like cactus extract, as well as vitamins A, C, and E for additional antioxidant defense. Sunbetter eCosmetics Formula:Mineral (Titanium Dioxide 3.5%, Zinc Oxide 10.0%) |Key active ingredients:Green tea and olive extracts help to fend off damage from pollution, blue light, and more. | Waterresistant?80 minutes |Size(s):1.7 fl. Oz. Our tester’s take:Some formulas are developed for daily use and others are meant for the times when your skin is the most sensitized, like after a visit to the derm’s office or if you’re using a retinol or acid. With a soaring SPF 75 from mineral protection, the cream gives you extra assurance that you aren’t accidentally incurring damage on your skin after spending money to help address an issue. On skin, it gives a slight bit of tint and wears comfortably (though it’s not quite as layerable as other formulas). Who it’s best for:People with a concern about getting sun damage, which is folks who’ve gotten laser treatments, microneedling, or are using a sun-sensitizing product like hydroquinone, retinol, or an acid. About the formula:Because mineral filters lay atop the skin to give you protection, it’s actually really hard to get a formula that is 50+ because they wind up having that lifeguard white-nose strip effect. This formula manages to be both cosmetically elegant and effective. It also has antioxidants like green tea and olive extracts that help to prevent from environmental aggressors. Neutrogena Amazon Walmart Formula:Chemical (Avobenzone 3%, Homosalate 10%, Octisalate 5%, Octocrylene 10%)| Key active ingredients:Silica for smooth application and dimethicone for mattified wear.| Water resistant?80 minutes| Size(s):3 fl. oz. Our tester’s take:Hurly says that, “Neutrogena is my ‘old reliable’ whenever I need a guaranteed great defense at a low cost.” While we recommend the SPF 50 (if you’re putting the stuff on, you might as well get better protection), you can also pick up the same formula in an SPF 30. It’s honestly a super versatile product that will work well for most people. Who it’s best for:This product is perfect for all skin types thanks to its oil-free formula (oily and acne-prone folks will especially appreciate that), and it even keeps skin looking more matte than before. The formula:The water-based formula feels light and airy on skin. It’s water resistant up to 80 minutes, so if you need a daily sunscreen for your outdoor activities, here is one that won’t break the bank—and won’t break out your skin, either. Good Weather Skin Good Weather Skin Formula:Mineral (Zinc Oxide 15%) |Key active ingredients:Squalane and sea buckthorn oil |Water resistant?40 minutes |Size(s):1 fl. oz Our tester’s take:It’s hard to make a sunscreen feel splashy these days, but Good Weather Skin has managed to do so with its buttery yellow formula that glides onto skin and leaves it feeling dewy and with an ever-so-subtle sheen. With an SPF 30, it's a really solid option for people who want a daily sunscreen that feels like skin care and doesn’t have that chalky texture that many SPFs usually do. Who it’s best for:People looking for a medium-weight daily SPF that they can wear outside. It has a slightly dewy finish, which should work for most people, but if you want something slightly more matte, go with a traditional mineral sunscreen. About the formula:Packed with sea buckthorn oil, squalane, peptides and niacinamide, the label on this SPF reads a lot like a who’s who of top skin care ingredients. It somehow does deeply hydrate skin while protecting it with zinc oxide. Particularly in the summer, you could simply wear this formula as a standalone moisturizer-SPF duo. Vacation Vacation Vacation is hardly the new kid on the block anymore, but its products have a cult following for their featherlight wear and great smell. Cetaphil Amazon Senior commerce editor Ian Burke uses this SPF moisturizer every morning in the summer—though he should really be using it year round—and swears by its lightweight feel. ISNTREE Amazon GQ's marketing and production manager Mari Herrema says this sun gel from Isntree absorbs quickly, feels light on the skin, adds a bit of a glowy effect, and has no white cast. Bioré Amazon GQcontributor Tyler Sparling—who “has theeeee most oily skin” (his words)—says this is the only sunscreen that's light enough for everyday use. “It does not feel heavy,” he says. “It’s the only way I can wear SPF every day.” Mineral SPF Versus Chemical SPF:This is one of the first things to consider when shopping for sunscreen. Do you want it to use chemical UV filters, or mineral ones? The difference could impact how it feels on skin, and how it applies. Face Sunscreen vs. Body Sunscreen:The difference between face sunscreen and body sunscreen is roughly analogous to the difference betweenface washandbody wash. The sensitive skin of your face requires a gentler formula than that of the body, and should be formulated to be mindful of things like acne, anti-aging efforts, oil accumulation and sensitive areas around the eyes. Face Sunscreen vs SPF Moisturizer:So, what is the difference between a face sunscreen and anSPF-packed moisturizer? If you’re going to be working up a sweat or going for a swim, then you need a sunscreen with water resistance. This will be promised in two separate intervals: 40 minutes or 80 minutes. If a product doesn’t say it’s “water resistant” as a benefit, that doesn’t necessarily mean itlacksthe resistance. Instead, it usually means the brand didn’t endure the expensive FDA testing to clear the product for that claim. In these tests, the product needs to prove its water-resistant wear for at least 40 or 80 minutes, and then those benefits can be slapped on the container. Even if a product retains its potency well beyond 80 minutes, it’s currently only able to promise 80 minutes of water-resistant protection. However, if you do plan to work out under the sun or go for a swim, make sure your product promises the benefit. Shopping for “sport sunscreens” is usually one of your best bets, but brands will definitely boast their water resistance if they earned the right to do so. For this roundup of facial sunscreens, you’ll see this time distinction noted or that it was “not formally tested.” When you’reGQ’s grooming writer, you get a lot of products sent to your doorstep. And of all the categories of products that pile up, facial sunscreen ranks highly with me. I never leave the house without a facial sunscreen on (okay, maybe at 9 p.m. I’m SPF-free, but never during the daytime). Needless to say, I’ve been testing these products every day of the past 11 years, and I’ve become a loud and proud advocate of daily SPF wear. The products on this list are those I would spend my own money on and which have the most universal appeal—not to mention that they wear comfortably and deliver on their defensive promises. Adam Hurly has been covering the grooming industry since 2013. For most of that time, he's beenGQ’s primary grooming contributor, too. For this article, Adam also spoke with NYC-based board-certified dermatologistDr. Asmi Sanghvi, who also offers Ayurvedic approaches to medicine in her practice. Ali Finney is a skin care expert, beauty journalist, and formerGQassociate commerce director. She's written for a grip of publications includingPopSugar, Allure, SELF, Vogue, Women's Health,andWell+Good.

title: How Long Does It Take to Build Muscle? Here’s the Truth
article_text: How long does it take to build muscleis not, of course, a question with a simple answer, despite what the TikToks or Reels promising to unlock the one thing you need to get big might suggest. In fact, they tend to raise many more questions: Like, should you be fasting? Or should you be cutting out cardio, relying solely on supersets, smashing calisthenics, attending military bootcamps, doing everything on the bosu ball, using only kettlebells, taking protein immediately after your workout, nailing creatine, eating lots and lots of beef, training at a specific heart rate, squatting with your partner on your shoulders, performing every workout without your top on, or adding a resistance band to absolutely everything? The list of suggestions goes on. There’s a gym obsession for everyone, but none of it will get you in shape the way that focusing on the (somewhat less sexy) essentials will. So let's go back to basics. This is the only information you really need to tackle the perennial question: how long does it take to build muscle? The process of building muscle is known ashypertrophy. We enter hypertrophy when we apply tension to our muscles during exercise. “This tension stimulates a cascade of biological signals in the body which leads to an increase in muscle protein synthesis, a process during which new proteins are produced and integrated into the muscle fibers, leading to larger and stronger muscles,” explainsHarry Cox, founder of London’s high-endClub Q Health. Resistance trainingis a great way to build muscle in the gym. Essentially, this means moving your body with weights to make those movements harder. A bicep curl with a dumbbell is harder than it would be with no weight, for instance. This is resistance training. The heavier the weight—or greater the resistance—the more our muscles are forced to adapt, making them grow stronger over time. Do it right and you can build muscle by weight training as little as two to three times a week, according to fitness expertPenny Weston. “You should always make sure to increase your weights to push yourself and ensure you are creating as much resistance, and therefore muscle trauma, as possible,” she says, referring to a method calledprogressive overload. To progressively overload your muscles, you’ll want to go heavier on at least two out of your four sets per exercise. Cox says that it’s important to do enough sets to stimulate the muscles without becoming overly fatigued. “For most people, this will fall roughly between 10-15 sets per muscle, per week,” he says. Which doesn’t mean you need to do 10 sets on the leg press in one day. Not if you want to be able to walk or sit down, that is. “I recommend each muscle group is trained two to three times per week,” he says. “Rather than doing 10 sets of chest in one workout, you could do five sets on Monday and another five on Thursday.” Then there’s the concept oftraining to failure, which is exactly what it sounds like: putting maximum strain on the muscle until you can no longer perform another rep. The thinking is that this fast-tracks muscle growth. Cox says “aiming to push yourself anywhere from 1-3 reps shy of failure seems to be beneficial,” findings which are backed up bymultiple studies. Everything from yogurt to cereal is touted as high protein at the moment, but does adding protein to your diet make a difference? We’ve learned the principles of building muscle, and the most efficient way to do it, above. But what about the actual building blocks of muscle itself? “In order to build muscle, the body must be in what is called ananabolic state,” says Cox. To get into this state, you need to be taking on more calories than you’re burning off. Think of it like a construction site. The more bricks you make available, the faster the building can grow. The same is true of muscle growth. “An adequate protein consumption stimulates muscle protein synthesis, which helps to build up your muscle fibers,” says Cox. “A protein intake of 1.6-2.2 gram per kilogram of bodyweight is considered to be optimal for maximizing muscle growth.”  In other words, if you weigh about 175 pounds, you should aim for a daily protein intake of 128g-176g. While it’s true that protein can make you feel full and is therefore a way to lower calorie intake if you’re trying to lose weight, it isn’t caloriefree, so you will still see you weight gain if you overdo it. Plus, your bowels won’t be in the best shape. “Carbohydrates are also really important when trying to build muscle as they are the body’s main source of energy for workouts,” Weston notes. Don’t sleep on healthy fats, either. “They are a great source of energy for exercising, so you can push yourself harder in your workouts and therefore build muscle,” says Weston. “Plus, fats are also so important for hormone and cell health, including muscle cells.” Sorry, but no. “I am a firm believer that silver bullets don’t exist, particularly when it comes to fitness,” says Cox. “The solution you’re actually searching for is right in front of you: consistency over time.” Weston seconds that: “Building muscle shouldn’t feel too complicated. Just stick to a routine, with proper form and allowing a few rest days per week, rather than trying to follow a fad workout program.” If you’re exercising a couple of times per week and have adjusted your diet accordingly, Weston reckons you’ll see results in about six to eight weeks. “It’s quite a slow process,” she says. Nor, Cox adds, can it be accelerated—without taking steroids, that is. “Many people will try and shortcut the process by doing more workouts or doing longer workouts and while that seems like it should work, it will often just cause more fatigue without any additional stimulation,” he says. Which brings us to a vital part of muscle building:notgoing to the gym. Our muscles are torn in the gym, but actually built back up at home, while we sleep. Skip this part and you’ll be left with lingering injuries instead of a growing body that’s ready to go again. “You need to give your body time to heal and repair the muscle damage,” says Weston. “Sleep plays a big part in building muscle because this is when our bodies release helpful hormones, like testosterone.” We’re all different, with strengths, weaknesses and imbalances in biomechanics that can make following the same plan a bit tricky, at least without the input of a personal trainer. With that in mind, use the below guide from Cox not as a bible, but as a rough plan from which to build your own muscle-building routine. The more you tailor it, the better it should work for you. And remember: “Taking time to build muscle through diet and exercise is best, so take it slow and steady,” says Weston. “If you’re not seeing results straight away, just know that is completely normal, and just be consistent!” Monday:Push (Chest – 6 sets/Shoulders – 5 sets/Triceps – 5 sets)Tuesday:Pull (Back – 8 sets/Biceps – 6 sets)Wednesday:Legs (Quads – 6 sets/Hamstrings – 6 sets/Calves – 5 sets)Thursday:RestFriday:Upper Body (Chest – 6 sets/Back – 4 sets/Triceps – 5 sets/Biceps – 4 sets)Saturday:Lower Body (Quads – 6 sets/Hamstrings – 6 sets/Calves – 5 sets)Sunday:Rest This story originally appeared inBritish GQ.

title: Is It Even Worth It to Become a Doctor or Lawyer Anymore?
article_text: When it was reported last month thatlaw school applications are up 20%, some of us who graduated around the 2008 recession thought of that one friend, the liberal artist-activist who, after six months of financial uncertainty, became conveniently passionate about the law. He got busy. He got a haircut. He got a Big Law job he never spoke about except when brandishing his pro bono bona fides. Law student applications are a bearish indicator—thebearish indicator if you’re young and insufferably promising. Morgan Stanley is revising up the chance of a recession. Gen Z’ers are revising up the chances Aiden takes the LSAT. He should check in with my one friend before he does. Big Law attorneys’ wages, which stagnated decades ago, show no sign of recovery with AI encroaching on billable hours. And the prestige associated with both Big Law School and Big Law is under direct threat from the White House. The Trump administration issued anumber of executive orders targeting lawyers, including those that have investigated him: taking away the security clearance they need to do business, inquiring about their DEI practices, promising sanctions against those that sue the government. Already, the law firms Paul Weiss and Skadden Arps have cut deals with the White House, promising to spend firm hours that would have once been devoted to pro bono work grooming the administration’s pet causes. (Other firms, including Perkins Coie, are suing the administration over the orders.) For the lawyers at those firms—currently getting roasted by debt-burdened but resolutely upright public defenders on professional listservs—capitulation isn’t just an inconvenience or ideological affront. It’s a violation of the deal they struck with themselves when they went back to school. The deal that allowed them to fig leaf their personal ambition with the prestige of participating in the broader social project of supporting the Constitution of the United States (and the constitution of the state in which they passed the bar). Eight months ago, I launchedUpper Middle, a publication documenting the growing discomfort among “comfortable” millennials. Consultants at McKinsey—another tempting career for wayward achievers—had just dropped numbers reporting that middle managers were the target of roughly a third of job cuts in 2023 despite constituting 17% of the workforce. That spike arrived amid broader white-collar wage stagnation and a surge in living costs in metroplexes. Then there was the cultural assault: Trump railing against the deep state as post-woke Silicon Valley broligarchs depicted the “professional managerial class” as a conspiracy of feckless, self-righteous elites. The economy was booming, but cocktail parties were ending early. When I began advertisingUpper MiddleonInstagram—where the millennials hang out after the kids go down—I expected to reach (and monetize) plenty of overcompensated, overcompensating senior associates and junior partners. I didn’t. Instead, I found myself writing for doctors, many of whom emerged from the pandemic having lost conviction in the broader social project of public health. They were exhausted. They were just doing a job. They sounded like journalists—my defanged pack—when they bemoaned careers that had felt like a calling and become a persistent irritation. We shared an allergy to fig leaves. Over the last few weeks, during the Trump administration’s assault on Big Law, I’ve had the displeasure of watching and listening to lawyers go through a similar process of discovery. They’re coming to terms with the fact that prestige and purpose can be pried away by power. Several attorneys I’ve spoken with have asked a variation of the question I’ve heard so often from medical professionals: “Was I lying to myself?” Very few have the courage to spell the whole thing out. “Was I lying to myself thinking I was special?” Special. Elite. Prestigious. Americans have a whole vocabulary to avoid saying theotherc-word you’re allowed to say in England. But class anxiety is what drives American overachievers to accumulate all those diplomas, certificates, and letters of rec. We hope credentials will close the gap between us and the owners of the businesses who cut our six-figure checks. But that’s not how anything works. As sociologist C. Wright Mills put it all the way back in 1951: “White-collar workers are often closer in their economic fate and social reality to wage-workers than to the owners of the businesses they work for.” We just don’t like to admit this. We don’t like the idea that, as Wright pointed out a few pages later, our status rests upon “sharing the authority of those in charge of the enterprise.” There’s an upsetting truth in there: Power that can be un-shared isn’t really power at all. Does this mean that the highly paid attorneys who graduated in 2011 have been lying to themselves this whole time? Was the pro bono stuff just cover for a collective boner for money, status, and box seats to the US Open? Not entirely. Like the pediatricians who used to push (really push) MMR vaccines, lawyers are motivated, at least partly, by a higher calling. And that is special. But they are lying to themselves if they don’t admit something has changed. They are no longer being paid to be members of a professional priesthood working in service of the rule of law. They are being paid to do jobs they have less and less freedom to define. In the absence of that freedom, the money doesn’t seem so great. But it’s not nothing. One of the time-honored ways in which the upper middle class copes with this kind of precarity is by leaning into its refined tastes. We live in a consumer society and, oxymoronic as it may sound—it isn’t—buying stuff with money allows us to express a sophistication that can’t be bought. If fits matter more to us than our parents, it might be because, 50 years ago, life in America was affordable and luxuries were expensive. Now, life in America is expensive and luxuries are affordable. In the absence of true stability, we can microdose wealth one Beams+ sweater or CDMX vacation at a time. People with multiple degrees might identify as former singularly gifted kids, but there sure are a lot of them. Except maybe we can’t. Tariffs make it hard to predict whether email workers will be able to afford Japanese menswear, Italian Illy pods, and Delta Comfort+ going forward, and a glance at one’s portfolio can kill the shopping mood. The tariffs were implemented knowing they would likely hurt, as Fox News host Harris Faulkner put it last week, “the 401(k) people.” In other words, the risk-averse institutionalists who stick their salary in an index fund, betting (patriotically and narcissistically) on the information economy—their version of America’s future. Those people are largely outside the MAGA base of service business owners, big-business scions, day-trading degens, and “real Americans” without retirement plans. Arriving amid attacks on law firms and universities, the message was: You can wait this recession out in your nearest law library, but we’re not going to listen to your highly informed opinions when you get out. When there’s nowhere left to hide, safety is about numbers. People with multiple degrees might identify as former singularly gifted kids, but there sure are a lot of them. Just under 15% of Americans now hold a graduate or professional degree, and roughly 21% of Americans are members of households with at least double the median household income, the traditional financial qualification for being upper middle class. Our reluctance to think of ourselves as a class has led so-called elites to vastly underestimate our own power. We’re more comfortable interrogating our privilege than we are weaponizing it. We’ve chosen to negotiate from positions of weakness, cozying up to authority rather than, say, starting managerial unions. We’re coy about salaries, stock options, benefits, and beleaguered 401(k)s—all the things that we like to pretend don’t really matter—denying each other the data we need to renegotiate our relationship with true power. But that seems to be changing:Big Law associates are organizing onlineandmedical residents are unionizingin increasing number. If the fig leaf of prestige falls, the upper middle class will be exposed for what it is. A bit hypocritical? Sure. A bit precious? Absolutely. But also knowledge-bulked and economically well-endowed. When I talk to doctors or lawyers about their work, their lives, and the misalignment of their expectations and their circumstances, I hear anger in their voices. The upper middle class is spoiling for a fight. If the powers that be don’t want to share authority—if they’d rather oil up and wrestle—well…let’s fucking go.

title: Even ‘The Last of Us’ Director Mark Mylod Was “Emotionally Blindsided” By That Big Death Scene
article_text: Major spoilers forThe Last of Usseason two episode two to follow. As the team behindThe Last of Usprepared to crack the back of season two, a unique challenge presented itself: How do you do justice tothe biggest, most devastating death in video game history? When roughly half of your audience is anticipating your next big move, how do you live up to their enormous expectations, while allowing the TV show to be its own distinct thing? Well, for starters, you call Mark Mylod. A veteran director who has worked on some of HBO’s greatest shows, Mylod was uniquely positioned to deliver this emotional gut-punch. AsSuccession’s lead director, he presided overLogan Roy’s beautifully anti-climactic demise in the final season. Prior to that he had seen off Diana Rigg’s Olenna TyrellandIan McShane’s Brother Ray inGame of Thrones. The guy knows how to kill off a character. “It is becoming a habit,” Mylod tells me. AsThe Last of Uswriters Craig Mazin and Neil Druckmann decreed, the demise of Joel (Pedro Pascal) plays out a little differently than in the game. While on the hunt for Joel on the outskirts of Jackson, Wyoming, Abby (Kaitlyn Dever) stumbles upon—and awakens—a horde of infected. Joel and Dina (Isabela Merced) then save her from the horde, who go on to storm and eventually breach the community walls in Jackson. Abby then directs them to a cabin in the mountains where her WLF crew are taking shelter. After a gut-wrenching monologue, Abby beats Joel to a pulp with a golf club (hard to forget that from the source material), before Ellie (Bella Ramsey) bursts in and is forced to watch her finish the job by sticking the jagged, broken handle of the club straight through his neck. Fans will notice the subtle changes, but most viewers will just be bowled over by the emotion of the scene, which is as punishing as it was onPS4. Putting it like that almost makes it sound straightforward, but this was a mammoth task for Mylod, as this pivotal episode—which also features a peak-eraGame of Thrones-style battle—is his first (and possibly last) time at the helm onThe Last of Us. He worked on it for six months from start to finish, across three separate snow-laden locations in northern Canada. A few days before the episode’s release, we hopped on Zoom with Mylod to talk about changes from the game, plans for an all-timer ofa one-shot takehe scrapped before shooting, and some of the moment that left him so moved he forgot to say ‘cut’. GQ:The last time we spoke,you had just killed Logan Roy. Now, you’ve killed Joel. What’s going on? Mark Mylod:It's weird. And it's a new form of character murder, isn't it – Character-ocide? It is becoming a habit. I killed off a couple of characters inGame of Thronesas well. So it is becoming addictive. You’ve come into arguably the biggest show on TV right now for just one episode, and it’s this huge emotional turning point. What’s that like? It's really terrifying. But, [writer] Craig [Mazin] asked me if I'd like to do the episode, which, and when I found out which episode, I couldn't say no to that. I was already a huge fan of the show, and the chance to work with [Mazin] kind of conquered all terror. It was odd to begin with, but the scale and the ambition of the episode was such that there was no choice but to just get stuck in and there was no time for nerves. How long were you working on it from start to finish? I think it was December [2023] to May [2024] roughly, somewhere within that zone in terms of everything from pre- to post-production, which for one episode is obviously a lot, but it was a humdinger of an episode. It was basically broken down into three stages, where there was three mountains—two figurative, one literal. There was Fortress Mountain in Alberta, [Canada], for a big chunk of the mountain work and the snow work, which had its own challenges, particularly to do with working at high altitude and in freezing conditions. There was the battle, which was a tremendous logistical challenge up at Minotti Bay, about an hour north of Vancouver, where incredible design team had built a version of Jackson. And then, of course, there was the work in the lodge [a real lodge in the mountains north of Vancouver], with the climactic scene with Abby and Ellie and Joel and the rest of the gang in there. And oddly, even though, from a production point of view, that was relatively simple—it's a room full of brilliant actors and a camera—it was far and away the most terrifying and the most daunting. Because of the responsibility of bringing that writing to life in a way that felt authentic and emotionally true and [lived up to] the history of the game, but also had its own life through our version of those characters. Had you played the games? No, I’m not a gamer. I watched the first season in awe with millions of other people. The thing that drew me to the project was this extraordinary combination of this morality play about consequences, about parental love, seeing love through this kind of looking glass… this dark side of love. Let's zoom in on Joel's death scene. There was all this expectation and pressure on that moment, and you somehow managed to live up to that. What were the challenges you faced in doing so? I felt huge pressure and responsibility to do justice to such a huge moment, but once you get over that and you dig into the work, then it's really about working with the actors to support them through that physical and mental strain of having to make themselves so vulnerable in those moments. That meant building a relationship with Kaitlyn and with Bella and with Pedro specifically. It's an incredibly joyful thing for me just to explore and push and prod and push till we feel we've got every single thing out of that moment. And to build to that moment of Joel's death, it was really just about supporting Bella, talking with her, so that when we came into the close-up, when we were really going to push and push and push to get everything out of all the reaction. [That] was always the pivotal moment for me, everything on her face—and just to work with Bella till we just knew [we had it]. There was one take where I'm just watching it, and the end of the take, I can't speak, I can't even say “cut.” There's that visceral emotional reaction to watching an actor's performance, where all sensible knowledge that you're in a room and there's a camera pointing at a bunch of actors and somebody holding a microphone, etc.—you're that lost in the moment and so, so emotionally blindsided. There’s a moment where Kaitlyn is giving her speech to Joel, and she looks over at the golf clubs and the camera shifts focus. And then just as the focus returns to her, she turns her head back and we see a perfect tear fall down her cheek… [Laughs] I know! I remember the time thinking, ‘Oh, my God, that is too good.’ I mean, just shot-wise, in terms of the camera operator and the focus-puller, [we] just got the exact pacing. You know, focus-throw and focus-pull can be so cheesy if you get it wrong, but that beautiful confluence of the work of the camera and the actor’s performance was just so beautifully encapsulated in that moment. Is that something you can plan for, or was it just good luck? I do think you can put yourself in a position to have good luck. My plan was to have that gear-change from the emotional outpouring of Kaitlyn's character in that moment, into the physical threat of the reveal of the murder weapon, and for the awful pit-of-the-stomach feeling that one hopes the audience is having in that moment. So the idea of for camera being there, and at the end of that speech, throwing the focus led by Caitlin's character over to reveal thegolf clubsin that moment, was very deliberate. The added beauty of working with such a great actor is that, of course, you know, she takes that idea and then doubles down on it with the perfection of that tear in that moment. Were there different versions of how you would shoot the scene? There are specific touchstones in my head. I had investigated the idea of a oner [a one-take shot] at one point. That was one of my early conversations with Neil Druckmann, because that's very much the style of the game. So I played with that idea. It didn't feel like that direct repetition would serve the moment best in our television storytelling. It felt like [we needed] the ability to go into those close shots and to check in with [the other members of Abby's WLF crew] and that discomfort. I find it fascinating that idea, in the secondary layer of the circle… This mission they've been on for, for so long, and here they are fulfilling that promise to Abby, but having to witness this extraordinary brutality that the consequences of violence, the way that's perpetuated through generations… Checking in on that psychic damage being done to those characters was fascinating and tragic to me. I was more interested in their reactions to the violence than the violence itself. And obviously, there were key moments, one of which we've just spoken about, that gear-change into switching from dialogue into action. And of course, just capturing those beautiful performances and that tragic triangle of Abby, Ellie and Joel. And I did plan that [overhead shot with Ellie lying with Joel’s dead body on the floor], pulling up that vacuum of hope at the end. There are some slight tweaks from how it plays out in the game – like Abby finishing it off by stabbing Joel in the neck with the broken club, rather than beating him. Was that to make it feel more final? Exactly. Joel has endured this beating, fulfilling the promise from five years ago, it's got to be slow. But at the end of it we wanted this utter finality of – in terms of creating that response in Ellie – there is no hope. That's absolute curtains. And that seemed a very effective way of achieving that. This scene brings to an end that relationship between both characters and actors with Bella and Pedro. How emotional was it on set? Bella, I know of old. I directed her first-ever scene onGame of Throneswhen [she was 11]. So we've known each other since she was literally a child. Rekindling that relationship was lovely, and there was an immediate intimacy and connection there with Kaitlyn and Pedro. Particularly in that relationship withPedroand Bella, I didn't want to be the gooseberry in the room there. They've built that connection over the years that they've been working together, and so I would step back from that and not try to insert myself into that. There’s a particularly affecting moment when Joel’s fingers twitch as he’s in a state of semi-consciousness. Is that actually Pedro lying there? I'd asked him for that on one of the takes. And then I remember watching and thinking, ‘Oh, God, that’s the desperation of pointless hope’. So, yes, he is doing that. Pedro is a traveller and an explorer as an actor. Each take is an exploration. What nuance can we find here? What is the level of pain here? What is the endurance? What is the level of acceptance of the consequences in your life on every level, from the huge philosophical and moral questions? What is the level of connection and awareness of Ellie's presence in the room? As an actor and as a director, we're working together there to try to calibrate that and find an emotional response in ourselves to any given moment. We’re running out of time, and we haven’t even gotten to the gigantic, peakGame of Thrones-tier battle sequence at the centre of this episode. Can you tell me a bit about the scale and the challenges of shooting that? It was actually really, really fun. Because, if you imagine, as a director, that you join a production that is like: here's an incredible stunt team. Here's an incredible AD team, here's an incredible VFX team. Everybody's working their ass off to achieve this incredibly ambitious sequence. And given all those assets, human and otherwise, you've got to be an idiot to mess it up at that point. And so it just comes down to working every single moment, from the big plan down to the micro level of, is that makeup right? Is that level of violence right? Is it cold enough? We just all worked our asses off. And I'd walk away at the end of each day, and it was cold and sometimes it was rainy which was not our friend, but each day I'd be replaying the sequences in my head with a gentle feeling of elation, a bubbling optimism that what we were capturing through this cumulative effort all these extraordinary craftspeople was was something that was going to be really visceral. I's an extraordinary kind of juxtaposition with the intimacy of those that large sequence. This story originally appeared inBritish GQ.

title: I Finally Found Better Shorts Than Patagonia Baggies
article_text: All products are independently selected by our editors. If you buy something, we may earn an affiliate commission. InGQ’s annual survey of theshorts market, Patagonia Baggies are never far from top of mind. Their appeal might be simple—an unbeatable trifecta of silhouette, quality, and price—but in the grand hierarchy of outdoorsy shorts with real-deal style chops, they reign supreme. Around this time every year, though, when the Recommends braintrust convenes for our seasonal Shorts Summit to conclude that shocker,Patagonia Baggies are still great, we also caucus on any surprising new contenders for the crown. And after putting The North Face’sClass V Pathfinder Belted Shortsthrough the paces in the wilderness this weekend—hiking, climbing, swimming, the works—they might’ve overthrown the king in my own power rankings. Because these are shorts predicated on performance above all else, let’s start there. The Class Vs are made from an almost-entirely recycled nylon blend that dries ridiculously fast, enhanced by a meretouchof stretch to ensure maximum range of motion (a boon no matter how much relaxation is on the agenda). They’re also outfitted with a webbed belt at the waist to make sure they, y’know, actually stay up, regardless of context, use case, or proximity to water. The North Face The North Face The North Face The North Face They boast a total of four pockets—two standard slash pockets plus hidden zipper pockets on either side—along with the aforementioned belted elastic waistband, a feature both simple and a touch more involved than its standard-bearing counterparts. I’m 5’9” with a 30” waist and went with a size small, the right move all-around. As hiking shorts, the Class Vs never sagged, even with a bunch of stuff loaded inside their pockets and an entire crash pad beating against them for well over two miles. Asclimbing shorts, they restricted approximately zero movement, even when I found myself contorted into pretzel-out positions that most non-climbers would describe as “no, please, god, no”. And asproxy swim trunks—because darn right they double as proxy swim trunks—they were dry before I even reached the car. (As someone who prefers a bit of extra breathing room when confronted with the choice, I would add that they’re a touch slimmer in the thigh than a typical pair of Baggies, though I wouldn’t consider them remotely narrow, either.) The belted waistband is a huge boon for anybody used to the Baggies' sometimes-flimsy drawcord. Hidden pockets—four in total, one more than you'll find on their Patagonia counterparts—kept my stuff secure on the go. Here’s the real kicker, though: at $65, they’re also just a few buckscheaperthan a pair of Baggies, and objectively more tricked-out—see: that extra zipper pocket, webbed belt, et al.—which isn’t quite the Baggies’ remit, but does make you wonder, well,shouldn’tit be, given the contextual similarities between them? As a near-lifelong Baggies devotee, I’m not going to pretend that the Class Vs willsupplant themin my closet altogether. But Iamresolutely stoked to have a pair at my disposal, and will be putting them through the wringer all spring long, officialGQshorts survey be damned.

title: Charli XCX Named 26 Potential “Brat Summer” Successors at Coachella. Here’s What They All Have Coming Out and When
article_text: By now, whether you’re a venerable Canadian body-horror filmmaker or a slightly confused Baltimore hardcore-band member, you’re probably aware thatCharli XCX closed out her Coachella performance this past weekend with a strobing video slideshow that bid an apparent farewell to the era known as “brat summer” and nominated a number of potential successors whose own season of zeitgeist-dominance might be imminent. Charli’s list of contenders to recreate her fingerless-glove grip on the culture in 2025 included hipster-household names likeA$AP RockyandBlood Orange, Charli collaborators like Lorde, Addison Rae and Haim, and cream-of-the-underground artists like Ethel Cain andTurnstile; she also confirmed her cinephile cred by including a range of filmmakers, from the legendary (David Cronenberg) to the cult-y (Sean Price Williams.) Like the shout-outs in the lyrics to Charli’s “Club Classics”—A.G. Cook,SOPHIE,Mike Skinner, etc.—it’s a very hip lineup that could double as a crib sheet for culture reporters curating their spring/summer editorial calendars. Thanks, Charli! But since those names flashed by very quickly—and in no particular order—we’ve created this quick-reference guide to the artists mentioned, in chronological order based on when their Charli-esque reign might begin. Who:Art-glam singer-songwriter Mike Hadreas; remixed Charli’s “Good Ones” in 2021, to intense quasi-industrial effect. Potential Summer Dominance Date:Right now—Glory, Hadreas’ follow-up to the acclaimedSet My Heart on Fire Immediately, dropped March 28th. Who:The formerly-solo project of Vermont singer-songwriter and prolific collaborator Justin Vernon, who appears on “I think about it all the time featuring Bon Iver” from Charli’s 2024 deluxe albumBrat and it’s completely different but also still Brat. Potential Summer Dominance Date:Now—the fifth Bon Iver albumSABLE, fABLEhit stores earlier this month, accompanied by an elite tinned-salmon collab. Who:Sicko/maestro writer-director of countless revered and influential movies, includingThe Fly,Crash(the good one, not the bad one),Videodrome,Eastern PromisesandCrimes of the Future. Sort of the original elevated-horror guy, although that makes him sound less great than he is. Potential Summer Dominance Date:The Shrouds, in which the widowed 82-year-old auteur explores grief and mortality via a sci-fi plot about an inventor who develops a way to communicate with the dead, is in theaters now. Who:The Valley's finest sibling pop-rock trio, known for hits like “The Wire”; featured on Charli’s “Warm,” from 2019’sCharli. Potential Summer Dominance Date:The official release date for Haim’s fourth album remains TBD; the single “Relationships,” their first new music since 2023, dropped March 11th, followed by “Everybody’s Trying to Figure Me Out” in early April. Who:Norwegian writer-director who broke through in 2021 with the female-antihero rom-com/dramaThe Worst Person in the World. Potential Summer Dominance Date:Trier’s sixth filmSentimental Value—starringWorst Person’s Renate Reinsve, Elle Fanning, Cory Michael Smith and Stellan Skarsgård—premieres at the Cannes Film Festival next month. Who:Swedish cloud-rap icon featured alongside Robyn on Charli’s “360 featuring Robyn and Yung Lean”; second paragon of “artistry” cited by Charli inher Subway Takes interview(first cited: Lou Reed.) Potential Summer Dominance Date:Yung Lean’s next albumJonatanis out May 2; a single, “Forever Yung,” dropped in February. Who:Nimble multi-genre collaborator (Tyler the Creator, Gorillaz, Kaytranada) and Grammy-winning pop singer-songwriter known for “telepatia.” Potential Summer Dominance Date:Sincerely, featuring the single “Sunshine & Rain…,” drops May 9. Who:British singer-songwriter known forHeaven Knowsand her 2023 Ice Spice collaboration “Boys a Liar Pt. 2.” Potential Summer Dominance Date:Fancy That, PinkPantheress' reportedly-dance-music-inspired mixtape, drops May 9th on Warner UK. Who:Long-running Essex post-punk/art-rock duo. Potential Summer Dominance Date:Crooked Wing, the first new These New Puritans album since 2019, comes out May 30. Who:Good question. At press time, it’s unclear if Charli was shouting out her “New Shapes”/“Everything is Romantic” collaborator Caroline Polanchek or the lower-case-favoring UK rock band caroline, whose forthcoming albumcaroline 2happens to feature Polanchek on several tracks. Girl, so confusing! But it’s a long summer—maybe they can share the crown. Date of Potential Summer Dominance:Polanchek wrote "Studio summer but still agree Love u @charli_xcx" on her Instagram in response to Charli’s shout-out; Rough Trade Records will release caroline'scaroline 2on May 30. Who:Preternaturally louche Britpop legends; the only correct answer to the question “Blur or Oasis.” Potential Summer Dominance Date:The new Pulp albumMore, the band’s first since 2001’sWe Love Lifeand the passing of longtime guitarist Steve Mackey (d. 2023), comes out June 6th; after a string of European tour dates, the reunited group will play two nights at the Hollywood Bowl in Los Angeles with LCD Soundsystem. Who:TikTok phenom turned pop sensation, featured on Charli’s "The Von Dutch Remix with Addison Rae and A. G. Cook"; also collab’d with Charli on the single “2 Die 4” and A.G. Cook’s “Lucifer.” Date of Potential Summer Dominance:June 6th, when Rae drops her as-yet-untitled full-length debut album, featuring the singles “Diet Pepsi,” “Aquamarine,” “High Fashion” and “Headphones On.” Who:Long-running Baltimore melodic-hardcore punks who took the mainstream by surprise with 2021’sGlow On. Date of Potential Summer Dominance:Their fourth full-length album,Never Enough, drops June 6th Who:Academy Award-nominated Canadian writer-director known for her 2023 debut featurePast Lives. Date of Potential Summer Dominance:Materialists, a romantic comedy starring Dakota Johnson, Pedro Pascal, and Chris Evans, opens June 13th. Who:Horror-elevating A24 auteur behindHereditary,Midsommar, andBeau is Afraid. Date of Potential Summer Dominance:Eddington, a modern-day Western set during the COVID-19 pandemic and starring Pedro Pascal and Joaquin Phoenix, hits theaters July 18th. Who:Academy Award-nominated writer-director of such films asRequiem For a Dream,Black Swan,The Wrestler, andThe Whale. Date of Potential Summer Dominance:Caught Stealing, with Austin Butler as a baseball player-turned-bartender embroiled in criminal activity during New York’s grimy ‘90s, opens August 29th. Who:Tallahassee-born singer-songwriter whose output includes the Southern Gothic masterpiecePreacher’s Daughter(2022) and this year’s even-bleaker, defiantly experimental drone-rock projectPerverts. Date of Potential Summer Dominance:Cain’s third albumWilloughby Tucker, I’ll Always Love Youis set to drop in August. Who:Arguably the deepest-cut pick on Charli's list; South Korean-born American video-essayist turned feature director whose films include 2017’sColumbusand 2021’sAfter Yang. Date of Potential Summer Dominance:If it happens, it’ll technically be “Kogonada Fall” rather than “Kogonada Summer”; his next filmA Big Bold Beautiful Journey, with Margot Robbie and Colin Farrell, opens September 19th. Who:Paul Thomas Anderson, writer-director of some of the most acclaimed American films of the 21st century, includingThere Will Be Blood,The Master, and the rated-five-stars-on-Letterboxd-by-Charli-XCXPhantom Thread. Date of Potential Summer Dominance:Again, “PTA Fall” is more likely—Anderson’sOne Battle After Another, an action comedy featuring Teyana Taylor and Leonardo DiCaprio in the director’s biggest-budget production to date, opens September 26th. Who:Scottish director/photographer whose recent work includes Billie Eilish’s “Birds of a Feather” video, Timothée Chalamet’sRolling Stonecover shoot, and Charli’s video for “360.” Date of Potential Summer Dominance:TBD—Zamiri is now in production on his debut feature filmThe Moment, an A24 mockumentary which he co-wrote with (surprise) Charli XCX, who’s starring in the film alongside Alexander Skarsgård and Rosanna Arquette. Who:Rapper, fashion icon, occasional actor, Ray-Ban Studios creative director, father of Rihanna’s children RZA and Riot.
